Yes it does.🙂
Sodium hydrogen carbonate solution is used in photosynthesis investigations because it provides plants with carbon dioxide (CO2), which they need to perform photosynthesis.
When a factor becomes limiting in photosynthesis investigations, it means it's the main factor that restricts the rate of photosynthesis.

In varying light intensity/investigation.  How could co2 be the limiting factor when the water is dissolved in sodium hydrogen carbonate??
Watching before exam

Hi there, please refer to our chemistry playlist for this video. 😊 and thank you
Simply click on the playlists tab on our channel page.
Thank you! Will do!
Most welcome! Glad to be of help.

During photosynthesis, plants use light energy to convert carbon dioxide and water into glucose and oxygen.  Sodium hydrogen carbonate is used in experiments to provide CO2 for photosynthesis. When it dissolves in water, it releases CO2 gas.  As you increase the light intensity, the rate of photosynthesis becomes faster.  As light intensity increases, CO2 availability from the NaHCO3 solution may not be enough to keep up with the increased rate of photosynthesis. (The CO2 in the solution may become used up, limiting the plant's ability to continue photosynthesis at a faster rate.)  So, as you increase light intensity, the rate of photosynthesis increases up to a point and then levels off or slows down, it could be an indication that CO2 availability from the NaHCO3 solution has become the limiting factor.
Wishing you all the very best for your exams! 😊
